See my responses below.

> In answer the your question, remarkably, everyth=
ing you see on the
> site started ultimately from complete randomness (i.e.=
 a completely
> random population of minimal NEAT CPPNs).  Every picture is=
 the
> result of nothing more than one or more people selecting images they=

> liked from a group of candidates.  So no, they do not start from any
> g=
iven pictures.  
> 
> I believe this point deserves emphasizing.  To me, it=
's pretty
> amazing that all of these pictures started from nothing.  There=
 was
> never an artist and no initial designs.  It's a genuine testament to=

> the power of evolution to produce complex results.  In fact, it is
> one=
 of the few demonstrations of this supposed evolutionary
> capability (i.e.=
 towards higher complexity and organization) that is
> actually intuitive t=
o the naked eye.  For example, check these out:

I agree. That is simply in=
credible. A standing ovation is in order for you
and all involved. Last nig=
ht when looking at the pictures for the first time
I was sure you guys were=
 'cheating' by seeding the images with photos of
cars and faces. 

> http:/=
/www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/picbreeder_collage.png
> 
> (press "zoom" in your=
 browser to see it at highest quality- browsers
> default to a worse resolu=
tion)
> 
> Furthermore, it shows the power of CPPN encoding that it could b=
e
> steered to such a variety of recognizeable objects through nothing
> bu=
t what is in effect a pop-15 greedy GA.
> 
> Of course the reason it was po=
ssible is because humans are doing the
> evaluation- which yields another l=
esson: The fitness function in most
> evolutionary computation is a liabili=
ty against getting to high-level
> complexity.  There are deep reasons that=
 human evaluation is actually
> more analogous to what happened over natura=
l evolution than any other
> type of evaluation scheme we run on computers.=
  We are often misled
> into believing that interactive evolution is less "=
natural" than
> normal EC.  Actually, the opposite is true.

I can think of=
 my own reasons why this highly controversial statement
*might* be true, bu=
t I would be interested in hearing yours. Why do you make
this claim?
> 
> =
The exciting thing is that this experiment just started.  Who knows
> where=
 it is going to go?  We didn't know we'd be seeing cars and
> sunsets but t=
he system and its users (who deserve a lot of credit)
> offer constant surp=
rises.  Hopefully people will branch from some of
> the deepest lineages (i=
.e. most complex, having been through the most
> generations) to go even fa=
rther down the path that they are going.
> 
> ken  
> 
> 
>

>>> From: Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>
>>>=
 Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>

Aug 2007 23:29:04 -0000
>>> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@...=
m>
>>> Subject: [neat] Picbreeder: World's Largest Collaborative
> Interact=
ive
>>> Evolution Experiment
>>> 
>>> Hi Everyone, 
>>> 
>>> I am pleased t=
o announce the opening of Picbreeder, a massive
>>> experiment in collabora=
tive interactive evolution, which happens
> to
>>> be based on NEAT:
>>> 
>=
>> http://picbreeder.org
>>> 
>>> Picbreeder is a unique online service tha=
t allows users with no
>>> artistic experience to evolve pictures in collab=
oration with each
>>> other. The technology behind Picbreeder is a novel NE=
AT-based
> Genetic
>>> Art applet that is integrated into a massive growing=
 "tree of
> life"
>>> that never ends. Anyone who evolves a picture they li=
ke can
> publish
>>> it to the world and thereby permanently add their crea=
tions to the
>>> ever-expanding tree of life.
>>> 
>>> What makes Picbreede=
r particularly powerful and unique is that you
>>> can *branch* from the pu=
blished work of any other user that has
> come
>>> before.  In other words,=
 you do not have to begin from scratch.
>>> Instead, for example, if you wa=
nt to a evolve a face, you can
> branch
>>> from one of the many published =
faces and explore an infinite
> number
>>> of variations from that starting=
 point.
>>> 
>>> Perhaps most intriguing is that we do not know what is pos=
sible to
>>> evolve.  As lineages are built upon lineages, complexification=
 in
>>> NEAT means that images can theoretically become more and more
>>> c=
omplex.  Thus, in theory, anything is possible.  In this sense
>>> Picbreed=
er's users are pioneers, exploring collectively a space
> that
>>> has neve=
r been exhaustively explored and discovering together
>>> creations that no=
 one of us could have discovered alone.
>>> 
>>> I hope that you will decid=
e to join us on Picbreeder as we explore
>>> this space.
>>> 
>>> ken
>>> 
=
>> 
> 
>
